title: Re-insights into origin and adaptation of SARS-CoV-2
affiliations: Emerging Pathogen Institute, University of Florida, Gainesville, FL, USA; 2
Department of Pathology, immunology and Laboratory Medicine, University of Florida
Laboratory of Transmissible Diseases and Biological Active Substances 14 LR99ES27, Faculty of Pharmacy, University of Monastir, Rue Ibn Sina, 5000, Monastir, Tunisia 15
High Institute of Biotechnology of Sidi Thabet, Department of Biotechnology, University of
Department for Innovation in Biological, Agro17 food and Forest systems, DIBAF, University of Tuscia, via S. Camillo de Lellis s.n.c., 01100
Institute of Biomembranes, Bioenergetics and Molecular Biotechnologies, IBIOM
abstract:
Following the recent report of a furin-like cleavage site unique to SARS-CoV-2, we characterized additional amino acid residues, positioned within the crown of the spike (S) glycoprotein, under diversifying selection along the ancestral lineage of currently circulating pandemic strains, and affecting enhanced ability to infect host cells. Molecular dynamic simulations revealed longrange covariant movements of SARS-CoV-2 S glycoprotein monomer in pre-fusion conformation with furin cleavage, and residue T333, under purifying selection, hinge of such movement.
Evolutionary analysis revealed that the current human lineage likely emerged after a recombination event between ancestors in bat and pangolin. Recombination impacted residues
